ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We are grateful to the governments of the Philippines, Kenya and the United Republic of Tanzania and local collaborating research institutions for hosting this research. These partners include Ifakara Health Institute, Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and Technology, the National Institute for Medical Research, the Tanzania Commission for Science and Technology, Sokoine University of Agriculture, and the Tanzanian Veterinary Laboratories Agencies in Tanzania; the University of Nairobi Institute for Tropical Infectious Diseases, the Kenya Zoonotic Disease Unit, Kenya Medical Research Institute, Central Veterinary Laboratory and the regional veterinary investigation laboratories in Kenya; and the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine and the Field Epidemiology Training Programme Alumni Foundation, Inc in the Philippines. We thank the Tanzanian Ministry of Livestock Development and Fisheries, the One Health Coordination Desk under the prime minister's office and all district authorities and veterinary workers who undertook sample collection. Thanks to all workshop participants for taking part in training. Many thanks to Beatus Lyimo for his help to facilitate lab work at NMAIST. This work benefited enormously from the support of the ARTIC network for generously donated time and expertise, in particular Josh Quick. Luke Meredith and Radoslaw Poplawski work as part of the ARTIC Network funded by Wellcome Trust Collaborative Award grant 206298/Z/17/Z. Many thanks to ONT for streamlining the setup of MinION sequencing in East Africa/Philippines and helping with logistical challenges. ONT provided some reagents for training workshops.
